That you are one of thoſe that vpon ſervice,
Were ſeene to carry Tomkins in your Gunnes,
And made a ſhift to diſcharge a league of:
Was it not ſo? that might take vp your bullet,
And ſhoote againe, and doe no hurt with it.
You a man of warre?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: S'life doe you queſtion it?
Ile tell thee Slaue to thy aſtoniſhment,
I haue bene ſtil'd, the rocke of Pirats, I;
I haue plowd vp the Sea, till Boſphorus
Has worſhipt me; I haue ſhot all the Gulphes,
And ſeene the navell of the world, you ſtinkard.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: How ſlaue, and ſtinkard, ſince you are ſo ſtout,
I will ſee your Commiſſion ere I part.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Strength of my braines, ſee my Commiſſion?
Ile blow thee up like a deck. Sonne of Neptune,
Off or ile fire thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I am grapled with you,
And will hang by your ſide, till you be calmer,
And be ſo, or Ile lay my trident on you.
Come to your tacklings.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Tis a bold actiue boy,
I ſee there's nothing to be got but knocks by him.
Giue me thy hand old Rover, hoiſe up thy top Sayle,
And goe in peace.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Sir this will not appeaſe me,
I muſt haue ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Reach me thy fiſt,
And be reconcil'd: what thou doſt not know me:
Though I am valiant, yet tis out of the road
Of my humour, to diſgrace any man.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: This will not ſatisfie me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I ſay againe,
Giue me thy wriſt. Know me, and my lodging;
Ile giue thee a Supper: there's a good plumpe wench,
My Hoſteſſe, a watermans widdow at the ſigne
Of the red Lettice in Southwarke, ſhall bid thee welcome.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: But I muſt haue you leaue your ſwearing firſt,
And be temperate.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Heare me honeſt Trojan.
As I am vertuous, as I loue my friends,
That I may ſweare.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: No, not as you are vertuous.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why then on my word, ile giue thee a ſupper.
What? I will not offend thee my good drumſticke;
Ile conforme my ſelfe, come to me at night,
And ile be as good as my word, old Bracer.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: But if I come, and looſe my labour, what followes?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Then Teucer, in pure zeale and verity,

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Ile belabour you the next time I meet you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What Scufler, doſt thou thinke ile faile my friends?
No Hector I ſcorne it. Ile pawne my cloake firſt.
Farewell Actorides.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What is he gone?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I, and as glad he has eſcapt from me,
As from the Syrtes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How he bore it out
With impudence?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Yes did you obſerue him?
There's nothing can diſcountenance him, ſtill
This is his poſture, he were excellent,
To venter at a Lottery.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why miſchiefe?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I doe not thinke he would ever draw a blank.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: We muſt purſue the project. Sup with him
At any hand.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The jeſt is behind to ſee,
In what a miſerable perplexity,
He will be put to entertaine us.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p:
You know father, for I muſt ſtill call you ſo, how you
charg'd your daughter to uſe me reſpectiuely.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes marry did I: and to ſhew a double dutie, as might ſuite with the reverence of your age, and honour of her huſband.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Well, and as ſoone as you were gone, ſhe had no more regard to mee, then if I had beene an old horſe, or an old Servingman.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Why tis impoſſible ſhee ſhould tranſgreſſe in ſuch a high poynt of humanity.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Elſe there was ſome fury in her ſhape that did ſo. I am ſure ſhe ſhapt me out to bee the ridiculouſeſt old aſſe in Europe.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Her modeſty would not permit it in her.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: If my words haue any weight in them; ſhe ſet as light by me, as by the leaſt feather in her Fanne.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Why is this true Aemilia?

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: No indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: How no indeed; doe you deny it? O palpable, ſhee reckond up a whole Catalogue of abuſes, and malicious practiſes, that ſhe would aſſault me with, if I were her husband, the leaſt of which were aboue all patience.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: Doe you thinke ſir, if I intended any ſuch thing, I would haue forewarned you?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: No tis not likely.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: That you had but heard the diſgrace ſhe put upon me, in calumniating the vigour, and ability of my perſon.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I cannot beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: And then terrified me, that the wind of her humour ſhould be ſtill againſt me, to croſſe me in every thing I deſired, yet the courſe of my deſtiny ſhould be more impetuous then before.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: The old Gentleman did but dreame ſo.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Nay more, ſhe ſaid I was an old dry ſtumpe, that had not the leaſt drop of moiſture in me, yet by the vertue of her humidity, ſhee would make my temples ſo ſupple, that they ſhould ſprout, and bud a freſh.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Come ſhe would not ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Yes, and that all my eſtate ſhould bee too little, to maintaine her in prodigality, and invite acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: Alaſſe good Gentleman, I told him how other women vſed their husbands, but I would conforme my ſelfe to obedience.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: I, that you might know what a bleſſing you had in her.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Oh was it ſo? I cry you mercy, I miſtooke you. Here take this Pearle for amends; I am ſorry I haue ſinned againſt ſo ſweet a ſimplicity.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Come I knew you were in an error.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Then to avoyd all cavillation hereafter, ſee what I haue provided.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What haue you there?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: I haue here a Syngraphus, a writing with articles, that muſt be drawn between us, before there can be any copulation.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Wherefore, did you ſo?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Looke you ſir, I was in a little ſuſpenſe of her behaviour, and therefore in relation of that, which I thought ſhe objected, yet has ſince proved to be otherwiſe: notwithſtanding theſe rules, which may ſo much conduce to my happineſſe, and haue beene ſo much advis'd upon with deliberation, I would haue eſtabliſh't.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Pray lets heare them.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: They are onely ſome ſew propoſitions, and exceptions to bee obſerved on her behalfe, for the better ſecurity of my quiet, when I ſhall be married to her.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Now I conceiue you, reade them out.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Firſt, that after Hymen has once joyned us together, ſhe ſhall admit of no man whatſoever, to intitle him with any ſuſpitious name of friend, or ſervant: doe you marke me.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Well proceed.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Next▪ if any of her old acquaintance come to viſit her, as Nurſes, Midwifes, and the like, creatures of ſecreſie, ſhe ſhall returne them word, ſhe is not within, or otherwiſe accommodated.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Ile haue it written ſo upon the doores.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You may perceiue by her ſilence, ſhee will conſent to any thing.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Then to avoyd alloccaſions of writing Epiſtles, ſhe ſhall receiue none, nor haue any Paper, Pen, Inke, or Waxe in her cloſet.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That's ſomewhat hard.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Shee ſhall not haue any maſculine bawdy Picture hang in her Chamber, but ſhall take it downe, and ſell it away as a thing unprofitable, and an inticement of phantaſie.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That in my conceit is very reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: She ſhall bid no man to dinner, but I will invite them, and when they are ſet, ſhee ſhall not caſt amorous glances upon them, nor drinke to them, nor licke her lips at them, nor ſhew her teeth when ſhe laughs, nor her tongue when ſhee ſneezes.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: For all theſe, ile engage my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Beſides, ſhe ſhall not take upon her, to contrary me in any thing, nor ſeeme more or leſſe wiſe then my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That's not much amiſſe neither.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Shee ſhall ſend no Hierogliphicks, nor meate cut in Characters, nor tread upon any mans foote under the Table, nor when they are riſen, giue them her hand to kiſſe, or open her palme to haue her fortune told her, nor yet ſhew them her ring, or receiue any of theirs, and read the poeſies.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: She ſhall know no language but her owne, nor ſpeake any equivocating word.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: In my mind now theſe lawes are very conſonant to a good diſpoſition, and if I were to marry my ſelfe, I'de propoſe the like.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: And for her religion, ſhe may pray to any innocent goddeſſe, as Diana and the graces, but if ſhe haue any thing to ſay to Mars, Mercury, or Apollo, ſhe ſhall acquaint mee with it, and I will preſent her devotions.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Haue you done now?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Laſt of all, when ſhe is ready to goe to bed, ſhe ſhall not put out the candle to walke up and downe in her ſmocke, and ſhake her body in the darke, and if ſhe be content, I take her as my owne.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: All theſe ſhe ſhall ſubſcribe to, if ſhee be my daughter.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Why then weele proceed to the Church?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Are you agreed or no?

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: Pray let me ſpeake one word with him in private.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Yes what you-pleaſe ſweet Lady, it is granted, were it a hundred pound to buy pins and petticoats.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.l: Tis not a thing Sir, of that deare expenſe:
Though you were pleaſd to tax me for that crime▪
'Tis onely this, time was, I could not loue you;
Though reaſon ſince, has rectified my iudgement,
And clear'd my eyes, that I can ſee my good.
Then I confeſſe I made a ſolemne oath,
None ſhould enioy my loue; but he that durſt
Attempt to ſteale mee; this is not intended,
For any perill to you, but for ſafeguard
Of my firſt vow, which I muſt needs performe.
Now if you pleaſe to come at a ſet houre,
None but your ſelfe, and fetch mee, I will yeeld
To goe with you, whither you ſhall command.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.l: 'Tis done bright Hellen, I will be thy Paris,
And fetch thee, though thou wer't at Lacedemon,
And care not a pinne, for all the power of Greece.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What are you agreed?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.l: Yes, wee are both agreed.
Some few ceremonies, and then wee haue finiſh.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Fido, I am now advis'd vpon a plot,
If it ſucceed, ſhall crowne my invention.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Something about the Captaine.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Hang him Kaſtrill.
I ſcorne to looſe a thought on him; my braines
Repine at his memory. Tis a new deuiſe,
The iſſue of extremity. Tis thus,
I will turne a deſperate Gameſter in loue,
And venter all vpon one caſt.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Take beed ſir,
There may be plots, but little policy,
Fortune and loue, are inſolent, and tickliſh.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come Ile doe it. Ile ſend thee with a letter
Vnto my Miſtreſſe, that ſhall make her mad.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: How, make her mad, what doe you expect from that: what can you gaine by the loſſe of her wits?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I ſhall gaine my deſire.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: And doe you prize
The ſatisfying of a lewd deſire
So much, to rob your Miſtris of her ſenſes?
Can you accuſe her of inconſtancy?
Or taxe her of diſhoneſty? Or will you
Prove falſe to her? what miſcief do you intend?
What hopes can you conceive, that may ſecure
So great a ſinne from Heavens juſt puniſhment?
Have you a drug or incantation,
And thinke to make her ſenſeleſſe of her griefe,
With the privation of her underſtanding?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Not any of theſe.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: If you doe, you muſt imploy
Some other meſſenger. Let me adviſe you
Keep her in her right mind while you have her:
Love of it ſelfe is an illuſive ſpirit,
And will enough diſtract her without helpe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She ſhall ſeeme mad but in appearance Fido;
And with that feigned frenzy move a pitty
From all, that muſt impute it to her ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Twere a mad jeſt: but is this all your plot?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No, this is not the maine one, theres another
Of greater conſequence, and ſecrecy,
For a ſound mind to beare, and tis a burthen
Worthy thy care and honeſty: Thinke not
I am ſo deſperate and heady, to launch forth
Into thoſe dangerous Seas without a Pilote,
And I have choſe thee for my Palinurus.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: You never knew a man of leſſe experience,
I doe not kenne one Rocke, or Shelfe, and Love
Has many.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Tis no matter, thou and I
Will ſinke a Paean to loves victory.

div.head: SCENA I.
div.stage: Careleſſe, Captaine, Lievtennant, Lackewit, foure Wenches.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.l: COme my voluptuaries, my ſonnes of comfort,
That know no ſorrow, ſing like Graſſe-hoppers
And feare no winter, nor no poverty;
Leade on my moving pillars of delight,
My Alchymiſts of pleaſure, that convert
All like your ſelves: can make old Cato dance,
And turne Fabricius to an Epicure,
Should he behold you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Thou ſayſt right Telemachus;
Tis wine, and mirth that breed theſe raptures in thee.
Body of Iove, there's nothing but a rabble
Of leane and ſtary'd imaginations
Accompany ſobriety: Some wine there,
That I may court my Cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.l: Good Captaine
Bid our noble friend welcome.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You know my humour,
To men of ordinary pretence, I ſeldome
Vſe to debaſe my ſelfe below the Nod
Of ſalutation, but for your ſake
I receive him as a man deſerving.
Give me thy hand Cadmus.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I deſire ſir to incorporate my ſelfe into your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Tis well ſaid, doe the like noble office to our friend here ſweet Lievtennant.

sp.speaker: Lieve.
sp.p: Sir he ſhall command my heart and hand on his occaſions, Ile as ſoone draw in his quarrell, as to piſſe againſt a wall.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Theſe are the mirrours of the time old boy, that ſhall ſhew you how to adorne your behaviour, that you may paſſe in all company with confidence of approbation.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And not erre the breadth of a naile.

sp.speaker: Liev.
sp.p: He ſhall be able to paſſe through the needles of all occurrences.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: And they would but learne me to ſweare and take Tobacco, tis all I deſire.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Come they ſhall doe it, and I muſt tell you, theſe ſuggeſtions in you are arguments of a generous diſpoſition, whence doe they flow I wonder?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: That mother wit that put them in my head, has put money in my purſe, and as farre as that money will leade me, I will be bold and wiſe: I have my humours, and I ſcorne the pollution of the Mechannicks.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: How doe you like theſe replyes Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Very well, by the faith of a ſouldier, excellent well, they are good relliſhing anſwers, and expreſſe an ebullition in his nature, ſwelling to conformity.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What, I will beare my ſelfe like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I, and the way to beare your ſelfe like a Gentleman, is ſometimes not to be able to beare your ſelfe at all. Lievetennant, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Liev.
sp.l: I ſay by Hermes, he that has a fortune,
And power to acquaint the world with his perfections,
And ſeekes to ſmother them, let him dye wretched.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You have no other way then this, to render you worthy of ſociety.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What, he may turne ſtinkard, and live in the Country with rootes and bacon, and not drinke a cup of good wine in a twelve-moneth, nor know how the yeare goes about, but by obſervation of Husbandry. He may keepe two couple of dogs and a Sparrow-hawk, and levell his diſcourſe by them. He may be ſtil'd a civill Gentleman, ten ſphaeres below a foole: He may marry a Knights daughter, a creature out of faſhion, that has not one commendable quality, more then to make a corner pye and a ſallad, no manner of courtſhip, but two or three dances, as old as Mounſier, and can play a few Leſſons on the Virginalls that ſhe learnt of her Grandam: beſides ſhe is ſimple, and dull in her dalliance.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: He tells thee right my brave Frisker, they are lumpiſh girles, heavy in their ſport, and cannot move with art.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
There's a wench, has her Suburb trickes about her I
warrant you: hold there Bellerophon, take thy Ocyrois, and mount her like Phlegon.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Now doe I want ſome two or three good oaths, to expreſſe my meaning withall.

sp.speaker: Liev.
sp.p: Captaine, what thinke you, ſhall he be a brother?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.l: Yes he deſerves it, let him be a brother.
Give him the principles of the brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Are you reſolved to be a brother ſir?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Any thing I, you ſhall make a blowing horne, or what you liſt of me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nothing can be ſuddenly perfect, but muſt aſpire by progreſſion, he muſt be practiſed in certaine duties, before he can be an ingrafted member of the fraternity.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: He ſhall doe any thing that is requiſite.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well then, for the firſt two moneths we muſt dine every day at a Taverne, where it ſhall be lawfull for any brother to bring his ſhadow with him; and beſides the full income of wine and proviſion, to beſpeake any ſuperfluous diſh that he affects: but that which ſhall moſt commend the diſcretion of your worth, is, that after the diſſolution of the Feaſt, no man beſides your ſelfe muſt know what's to pay, or take notice of the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I muſt pay all, muſt I?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You underſtand me rightly, and I applaud your capacity; from thence, we muſt have a Coach attend at the doore, to carry us to a Play, and at night to a Bawdy-houſe.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: And all at my charges?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What elſe? And if any brother need a Cloake, or a Sute, or ſo, you muſt not ſtay till he publiſh or intimate his wants; but preſently, by the ſtrength of your owne Minerva, picke out the meaning, and take order to ſupply him: have you any credit with the Tradeſmen?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Yes, I have a Taylor that will truſt mee for any thing that Ile have him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: That Taylor ſhall have cuſtome, tell him ſo; and one thing more, now brother, for ſo I muſt call you, we muſt have all things in common, no difference in the poſſeſſion of any thing.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Pray explain that rule to me, I do not underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why thus; this Hat is mine, and that yours, as you conceive now, but they are neither mine nor yours upon the premiſes: but may be transferr'd upon occaſion to either, as thus, doe you conceive me? Tis uſuall amongſt us.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Tis very well, is this all?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ile make but one experiment more of your apprehenſion, and have done. Looke you.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: O I ſhall doe this to a haire, and by the ſame conſequence I ſhall be a Captaine ſomtimes: ſhall I not?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Yes, when the date of your taske is accompliſht, you ſhall be any thing.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Tis enough, this once a weeke will render him exact. Shall's haue a ſong and a dance Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hang a Song, you ſee what little roome wee have for our mirth, and you would fill it up with aire, would you?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Nay, but by that aire, I hold a Song very delightſome, the very place, as a man would ſay, and ſuperficies of pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Cap,
sp.p: Prithee let it alone, by that element it charmes me into melancholly.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Then good Captaine let's have a Dance, for theſe Gentlewomens ſakes; beſides there be many that come to ſee nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why can you dance?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What a queſtion is there to a man of quality? Yes I can dance, and that ſome that are here ſhall ſee and feele before we part; for I meane to ſhake my heeles with that fervour, that it ſhall ſtrike them into a fit of my love, ſhall be worſe then any ague to them.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Wee'l try that ifaith. Come on Squeakers, racke up our feet and eares to your Inſtruments.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What tune Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Play us the fine Companion.

div.p: Well ſaid my efteminate Varlets, this was auſpiciouſly performed.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I am afraid this dancing will breed ſpavins in my legs, this caper has put me in remembrance of a clicke in my back, I got at my laſt vaulting.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No thou art deceiv'd my noble Hyacinth, tis a myſtery will exalt thee Hylas, 'twill make thee riſe I ſay, and put gold in thy purſe, thou ſhalt follow the Court like a Baboone, when a thouſand proper fellowes ſhall ſherke for their ordinary; 'twill make thee converſant with Ladies, and they ſhall give thee Diamonds to pawne, and thou ſhalt ride up and downe in thy foot-cloth my little Dolphin Some wine there Tony: I call'd for wine an houre agoe, and could get none.
Fill out ſirrah. What's here the Epitome of a glaſſe? By the wombe of Bacchus, a ſcore of them are too little for a draught.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: O Lord Captain, nine ſuch hornets are able to ſting a man to death.

sp.speaker: Liev.
sp.p: By Saint George he that dyes ſo, dyes valiantly.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What my bold Bravo, be not afraid, and thou wert dead 'twere nothing, Ile come but with a troope of Wenches: and a noyſe of Fidlers, and play thee backe like Orpheus. What's to pay Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir you have built a ſconce ſince you came in of thirty pounds, and before you have any more, my Maſter intends to be ſatisfyed.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What money have you brother?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Who I? O Lord brother Captaine, I have not the third part of it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No matter, I nere thinke upon ſuch tranſitory reckonings: come, lets have a health, and my brother Lackwit ſhall beginne it. Reach three Ioynt ſtooles hither Drawer.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What to doe Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ile ſhew you, you ſhall aſcend here, and be Captaine of this Fort: Ile inſconce you; come intrench your ſelfe, and play from your Battery, and ſo every man round, there take your Lintſtocke in your hand, and give fire, now every man as farre off as he can from the command of his Ordinance. Farewell brother.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, I hope you will not uſe me ſo, 〈◊〉 your brother, why Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: There Drawer, take him for a pawne, tell him when he has no money he muſt be ſerv'd ſo, tis one of his chiefe articles.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: How now, what are you preaching ore your cups? Now you are in your Pontificalibus indeed.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Good Crochet helpe me downe, I ſhall breake my necke elſe.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: How came you there?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I know not, an ill houre of the brotherhood, Ile after them with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: You muſt ſtay and pay the reckoning firſt, beſides the Muſicians expect ſomthing.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Who I pay the recknoning? 'Slight I came but now in.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: That's all one, you were all of a neſt, they are flowne away, and there's none left but your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: S'death the Captaine is gone away with my Hat, and my cloake too, I tell thee Ile pay no reckoning.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Tis all one to me, if you can ſatisfy my Maſter ſo.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What ſhall I doe Crochet?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Give him what you have, and if he will take your word for the reſt, Ile excuſe your Hat and cloake, and ſay you loſt them in a skirmiſh; you muſt ſcratch your hands in halfe a doſen places with a pin.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I ſo I will, come ſir, Ile goe in and talke with your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Beſides, I have another buſineſſe I came to tell you of, that you and I muſt doe together, you ſhall reape the whole credite on't your ſelfe, if you can manage it handſomly, 'twill gaine you that reputation with your Father, that you ſhall never looſe your ſelfe while you live againe.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: What is't Crochet?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Goe in and Ile tell you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You much amaze me.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Sir perhaps I might
With better judgement, and more thankes conceale
So great a wickedneſſe, but my true love to you
Could not withhold it, you have read ſome ſtories,
And theſe are things not unheard of in nature,
No newneſſe at all, the ſelfe ſame luſt and pride,
As well rules her that treads upon the flint,
As her that rides upon the necks of ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Stay let me pauſe awhile; ſhe is a woman,
Whoſe age and forme might tempt me to diſtruſt her,
But yet her manners forbid me to beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Beleev't? She is a cloſe Adultereſſe,
Of moſt ſtrange exerciſe, a Fricatrice
Inſatiable: and has ſhe none but you,
That ſhe can find to bayt with her allurements,
To cover her lewd projects? This moved me,
I'd not have medled elſe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O doe not wrong her,
Good ſir doe not wrong her, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: You have bin ſtill kept ignorant, for my part,
I never yet expected better from them
I count them but as ordinary chances,
Triviall, and drawne out from the lap of Fortune.
Beleeve me ſir, there is no day ſo holy,
That ceaſes to betray a womans falſehood,
My medicine workes, I ſhall be even with her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I ſought at firſt to make her mad in jeſt,
But now Ile make her mad in earneſt: yet
Tis not good to be too credulous; a word ſir.
I muſt have better proofes then your bare word,
To juſtify this accuſation;
Her vertue muſt not ſtumble at a ſtraw.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Sir tis not threats that can extort from me,
More then I liſt to ſpeake: I ſee you troubled,
And therefore will not leaue you in ſuſpenſe;
Know that I made my ſelfe experiment.
For all let this confirme you: this ſhe gaue me
Vpon the premiſes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O I ſhall burſt:
Here is a ſight to make the Sun run backeward;
Good ſir forgiue me, that I preſt you ſo,
Conſider't as your owne caſe: were you hee,
That put your confidence, your happineſſe,
All in a womans loue, and found her falſe?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe I thinke it would afflict me:
Ile leaue you ſir, I haue diſcharg'd my conſcience.
But of more ill, then ſhe has goodneſſe in her.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: How now what Planet ſtrucke? how doe you ſir?
This tis to be in loue: what alterations
It breeds? it makes a man forget his friends.
Come ſir be merry, your project has tooke.
She fell into her fit, ſoone as ſhe read it,
And tore the papers and talkt idly, and ſhew'd
The ſymptomes of the prettieſt lunacie.
What haue you loſt your ſpeech? thoſe folded armes,
And rownes, expreſſe a ſorrow, more then loue.
His eyes, though fixt upon their object, ſhew
The wandring ſpheare of his diſturbed mind,
Is whirld about in error. Pray looke up ſir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I am not dumbe, I haue a care within me,
Speakes to my troubled ſoule.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Why whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O heare it then, and witneſſe it for ever.
When ere thou feeſt a woman, in whoſe brow,
Are writ the characters of honeſty,
And cals the gods to iuſtifie her truth,
Sweare ſhee's a Syren, and a Crocodile.
Conclude her falſe, it is enough ſhee vowes,
And ſpeakes thee faire, the winds waite on her lips,
Straight to diſperſe her oaths.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: You doe but jeſt ſure

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: There is not one of them, that is the ſame
She would appeare to be; they all are painted.
They haue a Fucus for their face, an other
For their behaviour, their words, and actions.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Come come, theſe are but qualmes of jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Giue no faith to their brow: for in that greene
And flouriſhing field of ſeeming vertue, lurkes
A Snake of luſt, in whoſe voluminous wreaths,
Are folded up a thouſand treacheries,
Plots, Miſchiefes, and diſſimulations,
That man nere thought of. For in wickedneſſe,
The wit of woman was nere yet found barren.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I thinke he meanes to be mad himſelfe too:
Your reprehenſions are too generall:
For by theſe words your owne Valeria ſuffers.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Why there's the ſumme of all that I haue ſpoke,
The abſtract of all falſhood. Tis a name, will
Bliſter the tongue of fame, in her report
Is drown'd the memory of all wicked women.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Is your Valeria falſe?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Once my Valeria, but now mine no more,
(For they are periſht that haue loſt their ſhame)
Is falne from vertue paſt recovery.
The golden Organs of her innocence
Are broke, not to be ſolderd

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: In my conſcience
You wrong her, this is nothing but th' abundance
Of loue; will you goe and ſup with the Captaine?
And driue away melancholy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O no, my heart
Is ſhut againſt all mirth.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Then Ile goe ſeeke
Your brother out, and he ſhall goe along with me:
Ile ſhew him with a perſpectiue ifaith,
What a braue Captaine he has: hee ſhall be
In a diſguiſe, as my Companion,
Then if he will maintaine a Paradox,
That he is either valiant, or honeſt,
Ile be made the ſcorne of their company.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But my fate guids me to the contrary:
For if my Miſtreſſe doe not honeſt proue,
She has put a period to my life and loue.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.l: Come, be not diſmaid, what ere you ſay,
Ile ſweare it: you muſt affirme you loſt your hat
And cloake in a skirmiſh.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.l: So I will Crotchet.
Maſſe thou wert not with us at the firſt neither.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Why what if I had ſir?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.l: Thou mightſt haue carried
Away two or three of the Captaines oaths with thee.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: I can coyne them my ſelfe without any treaſon I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Oh Crotchet, I am thinking now, how brauely ile liue, when my father is dead.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Yes, pray let me heare you.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: I haue drawne the map of it already: Ile goe every day in my cloake lind with pluſh, and my bever hat, Ile keepe my whores, and my running horſes, and ile maintaine thee in as good a pyed livery, as the beſt footman of them all goes in.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: You will ſir, what ungratious villaine could haue ſaid this? where's your cloake and your hat? yes you ſhall haue money to ſpend an other time.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Looke you, doe you know this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How comes this about?

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Nothing but the fortune of the warres forſooth: my young maſter has beene in as ſtout a fray as ever the Genius of Fleetſtreet trembled at.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How was it ſonne?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Let Crochet relate. I ſcorne to be the trumpet of mine owne valour, I.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Doe, tell the ſtory, Crochet.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Indeede hee made them all runne away, that I am certaine of.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Nay but ſhew vs the manner of it.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Why forſooth I came at the latter end of the feaſt, and the beginning of the fray, and there my young Maſter was got aboue them all, and ſtood vpon his Guard, and held his weapon in his hand ſo dreadfully, as it he would haue powred downe his fury vpon any man that ſhould come neere him.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: And will you be angry with him for this? 'twas well done, take no wrong of them, better looſe all the cloathes off from his backe, then to keepe a cloake for his cowardiſe.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Now is the time to moue the other buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Well mother, if you will giue mee twenty pound more, Ile doe you ſuch a peece of ſervice, that you ſhall thanke mee for it as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: What is it ſonne?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Nay you ſhall not know, before it be done: the concluſion ſhall crowne it.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Well husband, giue it this once, and Ile vrge you no more, lets ſee how the Boy will imploy it.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes, ſend one arrow after an other and looſe both.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Nay, but giue it him for my ſake, I am confident he has a good project; you have example for it in your trade. How many haue you, that breake dayly, and yet their freinds ſet them vp two or three times one after an other?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Once more you ſhall prevaile with mee. Here hold, but if this miſcarry, nore aske mee for a penny againe.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I warrant you, come Crochet.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Muſt Crochet goe with you?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Yes, tis a buſineſſe that can not be done by one alone▪

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Well Miſtreſſe, pray throw an old ſhooe after vs.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Gentleman you are very welcome. What Hoſteſſe, come hither good Hoſteſſe.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: You haue a good handſome Hoſteſſe, I perceiue Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
She is cleanly and good condition' •
• hats my comfort, and by the power of beauty, if a man were combuſti • le, hee might find in her eyes, that would kindle a conflagration.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: What Gentlemen be theſe Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Peace good Hoſteſſe, I would not willingly proclaime their diſgrace: one of them is a Gentleman, that I baſtinadoed the other day; and now he is come to giue me a Supper, to be reconcil'd to me, but take you no notice.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Captaine here is a friend, that I would willingly commend to your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir as I am a true ſouldier, I embrace your loue in him, and thats as much as I can ſay. Hoſteſſe theſe are not ordinary gueſts with you; therefore you muſt be reſpectfull: and faith if you ſay the world Gentlemen, one of theſe nights, wee'l every man procure as many of our acquaintance as we can, and be merry here at Supper for crownes a peece. What thinke you?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: This is not the buſines wee come about ſir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I know it well enough. Hoſteſſe, prethee good ſweet, honey Hoſteſſe, ſtep and buy us a joynt or two of good meate, and a Capon, and lay it to the fire preſently.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Where's the money?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Death to my honour, doe not queſtion it, but doe as I bid you.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I haue not ſix-pence in the world, the Cobler had all I had, for mending of your boots.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Goe you muſt make ſhift, and get more then.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why if theſe Gentlemen come to beſtow a Supper on you, let them giue me money aforehand.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Speake lower woman, art mad?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I tell you I haue not a penny in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Speake lower I ſay. Goe borrow it of thy neighbours, Ile ſee it payd.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Yes and turne mee behind the dore for my reckoning; You haue ſerv'd me ſo I know not how often, no I haue truſted you too much already: you haue not payd me a penny for your lodging, ſince you came to my houſe, beſides what I haue lent you out of my purſe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Bane to my credit, you will exile mee beyond the confine • of • eputation: goe pawne ſome Pewter, or one of thy braſſe pots. S'light doe not diſgrace mee, doe any thing rather, take the ſheets off from my bed.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Yes, you care not what becomes of any thing. Why can you not aske them for money?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: S'life, a man may plot till his heart ake, and you ſtill ſeeke to croſſe mee, you will vndoe me in my deſignes.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: You haue more ſignes in your head, then hang at all the Alehouſes in towne againe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Prethee woman, heare mee what I ſay. I know they come to ſpend vpon mee, and will crouch, and doe any thing, yet when I out of my nobleneſſe, and beyond expectation, ſhall vſe them ſo curteouſly, 'twill be ſuch an ingagement, that I can borrow ten or twenty peeces of them at my pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I tell you I can not doe it, nor I will not.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Faith Gentlemen I muſt entreat you to excuſe mee, my Hoſteſſe is not very well ſhee tells mee, and I thinke ſhee is not ſo well ſtor'd with neceſſaries to entertaine you, as I could wiſh; and indeed ſhee has nere a ſpitt in the houſe, therefore wee'l deferr it till to morrow night, when 'twill be more convenient at a Taverne.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Well ſir, your excuſe ſhall prevaile, wee are not inexorable vpon extremity.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: In his you haue wonne mee to your obſervance for ever.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p:
Captaine I haue another thing to propound to you, heere is a friend of mine has lately receiu'd injury from one
Maſter Careleſſe, and vpon debatement of the matter, this Gentleman is ſo apprehenſiue of his diſgrace, that he can not poſſible put it vp with ſafety of his reputation, and therefore deſires to haue it determined in plaine field. Now as hee is informed, his adverſary accepts of it, and has choſen you for his patron in the quarrell.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By the ſhine of Phoebus, I wonder what ſtrange impudence has poſſeſt him. As I am a man to honour, I haue brought him ſucceſſiuely off from a hundred of theſe, to the perrill of my life, and yet am dayly obnoxious to new aſſaults for him.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Then you diſclaime to haue any hand in the action.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By the paſſion of valour, Gentlemen Ile tell you, I loue a noble imployment with my life, but for ſuch a pittifull, drunken, ſhallow coxcombe, I hate to be ſeene in ſuch a buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Doe you thinke no better of him, Captaine? if he be ſo vnworthy, I would adviſe you not to meddle with him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By the faith of a Soldier, if he haue any care of his credit, let him not deale with him, he will but defile himſelfe with ſuch an abject: I hold him to be ſo poore condition'd, I would not enter a Countrey Gentleman vpon him.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yet you keepe him company, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I confeſſe I haue done, and my intendments were good in it; I ſaw him ſo raw, and young, I was induc'd to beleeue there might be ſome hopes of him: but after much impulſion, when I found him ſo vnapt, and indocile in his owne nature, I gaue him loſt, and ſo I eſteeme of him, by my life.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh thou trecherous villaine, doſt thou betray mee to my ſelfe, and belye mee to my face? how many quarrels haue you brought mee off from?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Never none by Ioue.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will not raile at you, but I will cudgell you, and kicke you, you man of valour.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hold as thou art a man of renowne, thou wilt ſtrike thy foote into mee elſe, my body is as tender as a bogg.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou cowardly perfidious raſcall: haue I for this made thee my aſſociate, payd for thy ſwaggerings, and breaking of Tapſters, and Oſtlers pates, fed thee at a charge a man might haue built an Hoſpitall; drencht thee with Sacke, and Tobacco, as thy face can witneſſe?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh hold as thou art worſhipfull.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come ſir ſurrender your robes, that you haue polluted with coſenage. Here Fido, take this hat and cloake: I will not leaue him a covering for his knavery: theſe are the trophies of your treachery, theſe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay good ſir doe not pillage mee of all, ſtay till I get my owne againe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If Lackwit will reſtore them he may, elſe you muſt reſolue to goe bareheaded before your right worſhipfull fortune, with a truncheon in your hand like a Verger, and ſo I leaue you. Come Fido now for my Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well, thoſe good qualities that are bred in a man, will never out of him thats my comfort.

lg.l: And ſince I am the ſcorne of Captaines made,
Ile ſeeke a better and more thriving trade.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Come ſir, now I haue found you, not the power,
And ſtrength of fate, ſhall pull you from my vengeance.
And though I know thy life too meane a ranſome
For the redeeming of the priceleſſe loſſe
Of her abuſed honour, Yet what Nature
Enables thee to pay, Ile take in part,
And leaue the execution of the reſt
Vnto Hels iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What doe you intend ſir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Looke you: t' unfold your heart ſir with this ſword,
And reade the falſhood that is written in it.
Come I muſt know the truth, and reaſon too,
If there be reaſon for a wicked act.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: You meane about Valeria?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The ſame.
sp.l: Still an ill conſcience will betray it ſelfe,
And ſends forth many a ſcowling, fearfull looke,
To deſcry danger; if he ſtand confident,
And juſtify it to the face of terrour,
Then ſhe is falſe.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I heare ſhe is runne mad.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is, and the cauſe of her diſtemperature
Is the reproach you put upon her honour.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: The wound then is too deepe, and an ill Fate
Has driven the ſhaft of my intended malice
Beyond the ſcope I aim'd at.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Was it malice?
That word has ſtrooke me both with joy and anger,
Both in ſuſpence, which ſhould weight downe the ſcale
Of my deep burdned mind. What horrid baſeneſſe
Durſt ſo attempt to prophane innocence?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: It was my love to her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What is his hate,
Whoſe love has prov'd ſo ominous?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: That love
Being wrong'd, begot that hate.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Thou haſt done ill.
And like a fooliſh and young Exorciſt,
Haſt conjur'd up a ſpirit of that fury,
Thy art cannot allay.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Repentance may.
I only meant to give her name a gaſh,
That might be heal'd againe without a ſcarre,
Or any ſpreading playſter of wide rumour,
With helpe of her compurgators, but only
To vexe her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What's the offence that did provoke
This imputation? Did ſhe ever wrong you?
Maligne your wit? Diſgrace you before your Miſtris?
Diſparage your behaviour? Had ſhe done ſo,
Yet this revenge were diſproportionate.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Vrge me no more, I cannot looke on her
Without ſuch a reflection of my crime,
As muſt give ſhame a luſtre; there's no man
But once in's life may ſinne beſides his nature,
Nay perhaps contrary: this is a deed
I muſt abhorre to juſtify.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You have given
Almoſt a ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Twas a ſcandall,
Aroſe from my repulſe, and has no witneſſe
Beſides your eares; if it were ſilenc'd there,
The world were ignorant of it; I heare
She is runne mad upon the griefe, I am ſorry
Her puniſhment has outſtript my deſires.
Ile undertake, what ere you ſhall propoſe,
For the recovery of her wits, or honour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And Ile make uſe of your kind profer ſir.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I will reſigne her where ſhe moſt affects,
And give you all aſſiſtance to obtaine her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You ſpeake honeſtly, I ſhall imploy you;
I know you have that credite with her father,
You may adviſe him in a thing that reaſon
Shall ſeeme to ſecond; bring but this to paſſe,
You have made requitall for all injuries.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Shew me the way, Ile do't; be you the mover,
Ile be the inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You are my Genius,
My hope, my opportunity, my Fate;
And in effecting this you cannot erre,
To make me happy, and recover her.

div.head: SCENA I.
div.stage: Lackwit with a Head-piece and a long ſword, Crochet, Careleſſe diſguiſed like Dotario.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: HOw doe I looke now Crochet?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Very dreadfully: like a Citizen in a fray, as feare full as Priapus in a garden.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p:
Well, and thou art ſure there is but one of them, and
he comes diſguis'd like Dotario, to ſteale away my ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Yes ſir, and this is the old Gentleman himſelfe, and ſomebody has ſtole away his habite to abuſe him.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: That man that has done ſo ſhall thinke of me and this place as long as he lives for it: Goe and give warning Crochet, that no man withſtand me, unleſſe he be weary of his life.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: If any man be ſo hardy, let him take his chance.

sp.speaker: Lack▪
sp.p: Let him expect my fury Crochet. I will batter any man that ſhall come neere me, my fiſt is like a Sling, my head like a Ram, and my whole body an Engine, and I will make any man toothleſſe that ſhall offend me.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Then you will make his mouth as unſerviceable as your fathers gumm'd velvet.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I long to exerciſe my puiſſance: thou art ſure there is but one of them? ſtand by a little, and let me flouriſh with my ſword, to animate my ſpirits; now whatſoever hee is, that comes in my way, I pronounce him to be a miſerable mortall.
What haſt thou there Crochet.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: I imagin'd there would be a great deale of blood ſpilt in the skirmiſh, and ſo I brought theſe to wipe the wounds, nothing elſe ſir: looke you here they come.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Give by Crochet, till I queſtion them: it behooves a wiſe man to deal with words, before he deſcend to blowes: what arrant knight are you ſir? and whither doe you travell with that Damoſell?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Preſſe that point home.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O brother Lackwit, how came you ſo accoutred? or were you ſet here for a watch-man to guard us?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: No ſir, I doe not guard, nor regard any man, and yet Ile ſtand upon my guard, and this is the poynt Ile maintaine.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: What doe you meane brother Lackwit?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p:
How, I your brother? No, I ſcorne to have affiance with ſuch a conny-catcher: you ſir Neſſus, deliver
up your theft, or I will play the Hereules with you.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: I am going to marry her, my name is Dotario, and this is your ſiſter Aemilia.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I, ſhe is my ſiſter, but you are a counterfeit, and have ſtolne her away.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Seize her for fellons goods, ſhe belongs to the Lord of the ſoyle.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Thou villaine, doſt thou not know, if I were dead, and her other ſiſter, ſhe would be next heire, and then thou mightſt be hangd for her?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: But I had her conſent, and her fathers, my name is Dotario your neighbour, that have fed you with cuſtard and apple-pie a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I, this Gentleman has, but you have abus'd him, and tooke his wrong name upon you.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: I am the ſame.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: He lyes, beat him for lying, what doe you ſtay for?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I am conſidering with my eye, which part of him I ſhall firſt cut off.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Let's bind him faſt, and then lay him upon his backe, and geld him.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: A match. Let's lay hold on him; what is he gone? how finely might my father have been cheated, and all wee now, if I had not beene: that's ſome roguing Servingman diſguis'd Ile lay my life on't; if I be not fit to be chronicled for this act of diſcretion, let the world judge of it. Well Crochet, when I have marryed her to the right party, if my father does not give me forty pounds more, he ſhall marry the next daughter himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: You muſt not be too ſudden now in the opening of your plot, after you have marryed them.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Adviſe me good Crochet.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Why before you reveale your proceedings, you ſhall preſent your ſelfe with a great deale of confidence, and promiſe of deſert; walke up and downe, with a joyfull agony, and a trembling joy, as if you had eſcapt from a breach, or redeem'd your country: then when you ſee them ſufficiently fill'd with expectation, you may draw the curtaine of your valour, and ſtound them with admiration.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: So I will Crochet, come let us to the Church.

div.head: Scena. II.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Come Maſter Littlegood, be comforted,
I have as great a ſhare in the miſfortunes
Of your diſtracted daughter, as your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: O doe not ſay ſo, ſhe was all my joy.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: Then men begin to underſtand their good,
When they have loſt it, and an envious eye
Seekes after vertue when it is extinct,
That hated it alive.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: You have reaſon
To pitty me the more, and lament for her,
Becauſe I deſtin'd her in marriage to you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: And I had well hoped to have been made happy
In her affection, a true Lovers griefes
Tranſcend a parents.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.l: No, you are deceived,
A parent is confin'd, and his joyes bounded,
And only limited to ſuch a ſubject,
And driven from thence, have no where elſe to reſt on:
For if his children be once taken from him,
Which are the cauſe, then his delight and comfort,
That are the effects, needs muſt vaniſh with them:
But in a Lover it falls otherwiſe,
Such as your ſelfe, whoſe paſſion, like a deaw,
Can dry up with the beames of every beauty
That ſhall ſhine warme upon you, need not prize
The loſſe of any; you have no alliance,
Nor naturall tye commands you to love any,
More then your fancy guides you; and the windes
Have not ſo many turnings, nor the Sands
So many ſhiftings, nor the Moone changes.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: Sir you ſpeake truth, upon my knowledge that,
He is as ſlippery, as an Eele, in love,
And wriggles in and out, ſir, at his pleaſure;
He can as eaſily diſpenſe with vowes,
As ſweare them; and can at a minutes warning,
If an occaſion ſerve, ſupply himſelfe
With a continuall, and freſh entertainment
Of a new Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Troth I muſt confeſſe,
I have been a little faulty that way.

sp.speaker: Fon.
sp.l: And why would you ſir, knowing this before,
Suffer your daughter to be abus'd by him?
Now by my life, I thinke, and 'twere not for me,
You'd wind your ſelfe into ſuch Labyrinths,
You'd not know how to extricate your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Peace good Wife, ſince there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Doe not deſpaire, there is yet remedy;
I know a ſcholler, a great Naturalliſt,
Whoſe wiſedome does tranſcend all other Artiſts,
A traveller beſides, and though his body
Be diſtant from the Heavens, yet his mind
Has pierc't unto the utmoſt of the Orbes,
Can tell how firſt the Chaos was diſtinguiſht,
And how the Sphaeres are turnd, and all their ſecrets,
The motion and influence of the ſtarres,
The mixture of the Elements, and all
The cauſes of the Winds, and what moves the earth,
And then he has ſubjected to his knowledge
The vertues, and the workings of all hearbs,
And is an Aeſculapius in Phyſicke,
No griefe above his art.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Can he heale mad folkes?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Were they as mad as Ajax Telamon,
That ſlew an Oxe in ſtead of Agamemnon,
Hee'l warrant them.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How ſhould one ſpeake with him?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I brought him with me, he is at the doore.
Prithee goe call him Fido, you ſhall heare him,
And as you like his ſpeech, ſo credite him.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Is this the man?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: This is the Doctour ſir.
I am bold to make relation of your skill here
To this old Gentleman, who has a daughter
That is ſuſpected to be mad.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Suſpected, is ſhe no otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: She is ſtarke mad.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: It came by love?

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Yes ſure, what thinke you on't?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: An ordinary diſeaſe, and cure, in ſome things
I am of an opinion that Stertinius
The Stoick was, who held all the world mad.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: As how, good Maſter Doctour?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Thus I prove it;
What is ambition, and covetouſneſſe,
Or luxury, or ſuperſtition,
But madneſſe in men? and theſe raigne generally.
Your Lawyer trots, and writes, as he were mad,
His Clyent is madder then he; your Merchant that marryes
A faire wife, and leaves her at home, is mad:
Your Courtier is mad to take up ſilkes and velvets
On ticket for his Miſtris; and your Citizen
Is mad to truſt him.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.l: Nay he is a rare man,
And has done many and ſtrange Cures ſir.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I have indeed.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Pray relate ſome of them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: To ſatisfy your Ladiſhip, I will.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Yes good Sir, let us heare them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then Ile tell you. There was once an Aſtrologer brought mad before me, the circulations of the Heavens had turn'd his braines round, he had very ſtrange fits, he would ever be ſtaring, and gazing, and yet his eyes were ſo weake, they could not looke up without a ſtaffe.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: A Iacobs ſtaffe you meane?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I, and hee would watch whole nights, there could not a ſtarre ſtirre for him, he thought there was no hurt done, but they did it, and that made him look ſo narrowly to them.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How did you heale him ſir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Onely with two or three ſentences out of Picus
Mirandula, in confutation of the act; and as many out of Cornelius Agrippa, for the vanity of it.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: That was excellent.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The next was a Souldier, and he was very furious; but I quieted him, by getting his arrerages payd, and a Penſion for his life.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: You tooke a hard taske in hand, Mr Doctour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But the moſt dangerous of all was a Puritan Chandler, and he ran mad with illuminations, he was very ſtrangely poſſeſt, and talkt idly, as if he had had a noyſe of bells in his head; he thought a man in a Surpleſſe to be the Ghoſt of Hereſy, and was out of love with his owne members, becauſe they were called Organs.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: O monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I and held very ſtrange poſitions, for he counted Fathers to be as unlawfull in the Church, as Plato did Poets in his Common-wealth, and thereupon grounded his concluſion for the lawfulneſſe of whoredome; for he ſaid that marriage, as it is now uſed, was the only ring-leader of all miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How did you heale him ſir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why Lady with certaine pills of ſound doctrine, and they purg'd his ill humours.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: That was very ſpeedy.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then there was a Muſician that runne mad with Crochets, the fit was ſo violent upon him, that he would nothing but ſound perpetually.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How did you with him ſir?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I ſerv'd him as Hercules ſerv'd his Maſter Linus, broke his Fiddle about his pate, and ſent him away without ere a penny, and that brought his head in tune.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Ile remember this ifaith.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then there was a Huntſman that was very wood, he would nothing but hoope and hollow, and was wonderfully in love with an Eccho.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How did you reclaime him?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why I ſerv'd him in his owne kind, he had a very handſome wench to his wife, and while he was playing the Cephalus abroad, and courting his Aura, I turn'd him into an Actaeon at home, ſet a faire paire of hornes on his head, and made him a tame beaſt.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Husband that was exellent, was it not?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I cured a poet too, and indeede, they are a generation that are little better then mad at all times: I was faine to giue him over, becauſe himſelfe, and others tooke ſuch delight in his fury. I could not tell what to make of him, his diſeaſe was ſo pretty and conceited, and he was no ſooner well, but he would preſently fall into a relapſe. I could make relation of a thouſand ſuch, as Painters, Alchymiſts and the like, but it would be tedious.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Nay ſir, wee are confirm'd of your skill. Will you haue my daughter brought forth to you ſir, that you may ſee her in her fit?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No by no meanes, 'twill ſpend her ſpirits too much. Ile take her home with mee, and anoynt her browes with a little Helleborum, and ſome other receipts that Ile giue her, and Ile warrant you, Ile bring her ſafe too in three houres, and well recovered.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, you will doe an office, that will not more deſerue honour then reward.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall deſire nothing but my paines for my ſatiſfaction.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Good ſweet Fido conduct him in, and goe along with him, that if any heereafter ſhall be ſo averſe, in his ignorance, to all goodneſſe, as to queſtion this miracle, you may be produc'd as a witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: And what will you doe ſweet wife?

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Why Ile ſtay heere, and expect my ſonne Lackwit, with his project. He ſent mee word he would come preſently, and ſee where he enters.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Crochet, bid them ſtay without, till I call for them. Make roome there, and let ſuch produce there Game, that haue good cardes to ſhew.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How now ſonne Lackwit; whither away ſo furious?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: I am ſure all the wit and valour I had, was at ſtake for it.

sp.speaker: Lit
sp.p: Why whats the matter

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: There was old ſhuffling and cuting amongſt them, and I had not ſpied their knavery they might haue put a tricke vpon vs, faith.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Why were you at cardes ſonne?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: No, I was at dice. I came the Caſter with ſome of them I thinke, and I had like to haue made their bones rattle for it. There was a Rooke would haue gone at In and In with my ſiſter, if I had not made a third man, he would haue ſwept all away, and wiped our noſes when he had done.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Tell vs how was it ſonne?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: No matter how; but if I haue not playd the wiſe man now, and done an act worthy of applauſe, let mee bee hiſt off for my labour.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Letts heare, what is it?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: If it be no more thankes worthy, Ile tell you at my leaſure, when you haue prepar'd your vnderſtanding.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What is it Crochet?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Peace ſirrah, Ile haue no man tell it but my ſelfe, becauſe the prayſe of it belongs wholy to mee; and I could but effect halfe a dozen more ſuch exployts, Ide write my owne Commentaries.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: You put vs too much into a longing, ſonne.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Well I am content to open the ſluſes of your happineſſ • ; let them in Crochet, but take heed you be not too greedy of it, leſt the ſodaine joy overwhelme you.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Whats heere, Maſter Dotario, and my daughter Aemilia, hand in hand, & married together? Nay then tis as I would haue it. The boy has done well, and I muſt applaud him for it.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: O muſt you ſo ſir? Well, there they are Barke and Tree, but as I am a hairy beaſt, if I had not been, they had been as farre a ſunder, as Temple barre and Algate.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: How ſo ſonne?

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Why Ile ſhew you. there was an other Changling as like to him in ſhape, as Iupiter to Amphitrue, nay if I ſhould ſay, as I am to, let mee ſee what?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: To a foole.

sp.speaker: Lack
sp.p: No, to my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Tis all one.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: That would haue married her in his ſtead, and carried her away, if I had not prevented them.

div.p: Whether it bee a ſhadow or a ghoſt, that haunts him in his owne proper forme, I know not, but there he comes againe.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Why, how now ſonne Dotario, you haue made haſte to beget one ſo like you already.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O ſir, tis I am cheated, guld, and abus'd, and which is worſe, by one that ſayes he is my ſelfe too.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Why what are you?

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O ſir I am that old Gentleman, that ſhould haue married your daughter, and there's an Aſmodeus, a devill in my habit, that has beguild me of her.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Come ſir uncaſe, your ſelfe; tis no glory for you to lurke any longer under the perſon of ſuch a wretch.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Who is here, my Nephew Careleſſe? nay then tis ten times worſe then I thought of: my diſgrace will bee as common as Conduit water, the very Tankard-bearers will mocke at me, I ſhall be made their laughter at Tavernes, the table talke at Ordinaries.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay good Vncle doe not thinke ſo ill of me, abrace of thouſands ſhall chaine up my tongue, that you may liue as conceal'd as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: O ſir you haue proved your ſelfe to bee a fine Companion.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Nay hold up your head ſir, this was your deviſe, your maſter peece of wit, and valour? nay you may bragge of it, the credit belongs to you.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Crotchet I would thou wert a poſt, that I might beat out my braines againſt thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Saue you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Looke you ſir; here's the Doctor, and your daughter already.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Well there's ſome comfort yet to make amends for the reſt.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Come downe on your knees ſir.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: How now what are you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Lately the Doctor, but now your ſonne Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: What more gulleries yet? they haue coſend mee of my daughters, I hope they will cheate me of my wife too: haue you any more of theſe tricks to ſhew, ha?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No more ſir, if we may obtaine your favour for theſe, and thinke good ſir what loue may doe; you haue beene young your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Troth and ſo I haue, and beene as waggiſh as the beſt of you. Well Maſter Dotario, what ſhall we doe? the boyes haue out ſtript us, there's now no remedy, and my affection relents.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: So does mine too, and I would doe any thing, if I might bee freed of this ignominie, that it might not bee knowne what a foole this loue has made of me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Ile undertake for that ſir if you will yeeld to a motion.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Any thing upon theſe termes.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Then thus: you are rich, and your Nephew Aurelio here is poore, yet hee was borne to an inheritance; now doe you but conferre ſomething preſently upon him, and aſſure him the reſt after your death, and Ile promiſe they ſhall obſerue you with as much obſequiouſneſſe, as you deſire.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: And what ſhall my Nephew Careleſſe doe?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Why Maſter Littlegood ſhall giue him his Land againe.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: If he will doe one, Ile doe the other.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: That he ſhall, Ile ſee that done upon my word.

sp.speaker: Lit.
sp.p: Ile not ſtand againſt a good motion at any time.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.p: Why then boyes be happy in your Miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir this ſpeech from you is more comfortable then if Hymen had ſpoke it: and for my brother Lackwit Ile take him to my protection, and ſtand in his defence againſt all machinous Engines that ſhall bee planted for the battery of his wit and fortune.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Pray ſir will you get him his cloake and hat againe that he loſt in the skirmiſh.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I ſo I will; Fido ſhall reſtore them to him.

sp.speaker: Lack.
sp.p: Well I would know, how all theſe things had come to ſo good perfection but for me now.

sp.speaker: Crot.
sp.p: Nay, if fortune ſhould not favour ſuch as you and I are, ſhee would leaue her old wont.

div.stage: Enter Captaine like an Hoſt, Lieutenant with a Iugge and glaſſe, Hoſteſſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What's my old Reformado come againe?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay you need not feare me now, I am as mild as my beere: I am her husband and your Hoſt till death.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What turn'd Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Yes, and I thought it my duety to preſent you with the firſt fruits of my profeſſion. Fill out a glaſſe Tapſter, that I may drinke to this good company. Gentlemen you are all welcome.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Is this your Tapſter Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Yes, and does he not ſuit well with his function? he has learnt already to runne up ſtaires and downe ſtaires, as nimble as a Squirill, and can anſwer to any man that ſhall call him, as loud and peremptorily as the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thats a good entrance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: He is a little out of countenance at the firſt, but when you come to my houſe, you ſhall heare him ſpeake in a big accent, whats to pay in the Lyon? whats to pay in the Dragon? be not diſmaid Tapſter, be not diſmaid.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well I perceiue we muſt keepe Holiday: there's nothing angers me now, but Maſter Spruſe is diſappoynted of his Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Take no care for that, I haue more Miſtreſſes then I can tell what to doe with.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir I haue a ſiſter, though ſhee had no part in this buſines, yet for her beauty, vertues, and Dowry, may well deſerue you: if you can like of her, Ile doe what I can to obtaine her for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir you ſhall command mee in what you pleaſe, and my thankes for your loue; and here I vow never to diſſemble any more in this kind, but to be truely and ſincerely affectionated to whom ſoever you ſhall commend me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay if you would not doe ſo, you were unworthy of her.

lg.l: To gaine a womans loue thus all may ſtriue,
But wealth ſhall be put backe, when wit ſhall thriue.
